issues.description: Inner-artifact inconsistency in the problem statement: the UML diagram (lines 59-76 of the problem statement) defines the class as "Course" while every other part of the problem and the provided code refer to the class as "Lecture". This naming mismatch can confuse students about which class the UML is describing (they may wonder whether they should implement a class named Course or Lecture) and undermines the explicit instruction to follow the UML order for the Lecture constructor/attributes.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML diagram in the problem statement so the class name matches the rest of the exercise (rename "Course" to "Lecture"). This keeps the UML, textual description, template, and solution consistent and avoids student confusion about which class to implement.

issues.description: The UML diagram in the problem statement declares the class as "Course" while the textual description, template code (Lecture.java) and solution code all refer to the class as "Lecture". This inconsistent class name can confuse students about which class they are expected to implement and map the UML to the provided template.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class name consistent across artifacts. Preferably update the UML in problem_statement.md to declare "class Lecture { ... }" (replace "Course" with "Lecture") so the diagram matches the textual description, the template Lecture.java, and the solution Lecture.java. Alternatively, if the intended name is Course, rename the template and solution files and all references accordingly, but changing the UML to Lecture is the least disruptive correction.
